title: RS22044
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) provides federal funding to states for education of children with disabilities, requiring states to offer a free, appropriate public education (FAPE) to all such children. Prior to P.L. 105-17 in 1997, states had to ensure participation of disabled children in private schools, with benefits comparable to those in public schools. Prior to P.L. 105-17, regulations required local education agencies to provide equitable participation in program benefits for private school students, with benefits comparable to those in public schools. The vague statute led to differences among states and courts regarding services for children with disabilities in private schools. The IDEA Amendments of 1997 replaced the "equitable participation" standard with a provision for children with disabilities in private schools to receive special education and related services. The Supreme Court had conflicting views on this issue before Congress revised the law. The IDEA Amendments of 1997 replaced the "equitable participation" standard with a provision for children with disabilities in private schools to receive special education and related services, including on the premises of private schools. The 2004 reauthorization made further changes to these provisions, ensuring that children with disabilities enrolled in private schools, including parochial schools, are identified and provided with necessary services. The 2004 reauthorization of the IDEA made changes to provisions ensuring children with disabilities in private schools, including parochial schools, receive necessary services. The intent was to clarify responsibilities of local educational agencies to provide fair and equitable services to these children. The 2004 reauthorization of the IDEA clarified responsibilities of local educational agencies to provide services to children with disabilities in private schools, either through placement by the agency or parents. The cost of private school placement is covered by the agency unless certain findings are made. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified that children with disabilities can be placed in private schools by either the agency or parents. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA clarified that children with disabilities can be placed in private schools by either the agency or parents within the school district served by the LEA. This change aimed to protect LEAs from having to work with private schools across district lines, but has raised concerns about funding formula changes, conflicts with state laws, and requirements for children parentally placed in private schools. The new law under the 2004 reauthorization of IDEA requires LEAs to consult with private school officials and parents of children with disabilities on how special education services will be provided, including types of services, apportionment of funds, and decision-making processes. LEAs must also provide written explanations if services are not provided. The new law under the 2004 reauthorization of IDEA mandates LEAs to consult with private school officials and parents of children with disabilities on providing special education services, including fund allocation and decision-making processes. Private school representatives must sign a written affirmation of the consultation, and compliance procedures are outlined in P.L. 108-446. The 2004 reauthorization of IDEA requires LEAs to consult with private school officials and parents of children with disabilities for providing special education services. Private school officials can file a complaint with the SEA if they believe the consultation was not meaningful. If dissatisfied, they can submit a complaint to the Secretary of Education. Services provided to private school pupils must be secular, neutral, and nonideological, and funds for these services are controlled by a public agency. The new law regarding special education services for private school pupils states that funds will be controlled by a public agency. Reimbursement for private school placement costs may be reduced or denied if certain notice requirements are not met, but exceptions exist in cases where the parent was prevented from providing notice, was unaware of the requirement, or if compliance would harm the child. The new law on special education services for private school pupils states that reimbursement for placement costs may not be reduced or denied if the parent was prevented from providing notice, unaware of the requirement, or if compliance would harm the child. The law also allows for exceptions if the parent is illiterate, cannot write in English, or if compliance would result in serious emotional harm to the child. The Supreme Court's recent decision in Board of Education of the City School District of the City of New York v. Tom F. ruled that parents of a child with a disability are entitled to private school reimbursement, even if the student never received special education services from the school district. This decision does not set a precedent for lower courts. In Board of Education of the City School District of the City of New York v.
